title: 113_s1266
content: The Act titled "Refinancing Education Funding to Invest (REFI) for the Future Act of 2013" aims to address findings and purposes related to education funding. Congress finds that there is a significant amount of outstanding student loan debt in the United States, including a substantial portion in private education loans. The limited number of lenders in the private education loan marketplace hinders borrowers' ability to manage their loans effectively, leading to excessive debt burdens and potential default. This excessive student indebtedness has negative impacts on economic activity, homeownership, small business growth, and economic expansion in rural communities. The Act aims to promote economic growth by allowing borrowers of private education loans to refinance their loans, fostering competition, addressing inefficiencies, encouraging innovation, and attracting private capital into the market. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "private education loan" is defined as in the Truth in Lending Act. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Treasury, not the Secretary of Education. SEC. 4. TEMPORARY AUTHORITY TO CREATE A CREDIT FACILITY TO INCREASE MARKET EFFICIENCY IN THE STUDENT LOAN MARKET. The Secretary is authorized to establish lending, purchase, and credit facilities to assist borrowers with refinancing opportunities and reduce delinquency on private education loans. The Secretary is authorized to establish lending, purchase, and credit facilities to assist borrowers with refinancing opportunities and reduce delinquency and default on private education loans. This aims to benefit borrowers with high debt service obligations relative to their income and ensure lower interest rates to support economically productive activities like home purchases and small business formation. The determination is made jointly with the Secretary of Education and the Director of the. The Secretary, in consultation with the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection, must establish a compliance system before setting up a facility under this subsection. Mechanisms established should not result in any net cost to the Federal Government, as determined jointly by the Secretary, the Secretary of Education, and the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. Prior to exercising authority, the Secretary must publish a notice in the Federal Register seeking comments on terms, methodology, loan modifications, and relief for borrowers with high debt-to-income ratios. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress within 90 days of the Act's enactment, outlining a plan to implement credit mechanisms, describing macroeconomic benefits, and explaining how private education loan borrowers will benefit from the authority granted. The Secretary will provide annual reports to Congress on the utilization and impact of programs established under the authority granted. Additionally, a national awareness campaign will be launched to inform private education loan borrowers about the benefits of these programs. The Secretary will launch a national awareness campaign targeting borrowers with high private education loan debt. Any new lending activities under the Act must cease within three years of establishing a credit facility. Congress urges Federal financial institutions and federally chartered private entities to consider using available authorities to assist borrowers of private education loans in refinancing existing loans without increasing costs to taxpayers.
